Body: I used to think this was the beginning of your story. Memory is a strange thing. It doesn't work like I thought it did. We are so bound by time, by its order.

The film benefits immensely from repeat viewings. Its third-act plot twist alters the context of the entire film, beginning with Louise's opening words, which are not only a rumination on memory, but an attempt to explain her own unique, nonlinear relationship to it.
Louise's half-circle lamp in the upper right resembles the Shell, and even appears to hover in the air over the water.

The film's memory sequences are largely conveyed through extremely tactile shallow-focus shots, emphasizing touch and sensation. The first of these shots invites us to feel the touch of Hannah's hand, even before Hannah fully enters the frame.

I love you.

I hate you!

These quick POV shots do so much to align us with Louise's perspective as a mother, and the joy which -- in one quick cut -- turns to pain as Hannah both enters her rebellious preteen years, and approaches the date of her death.
Placed in the background behind Hannah and the doctor, Louise looks small and confined, utterly powerless even though she's foreseen this moment for years.

In repeating this line, Louise not only calls back tragically to her doomed daughter's birth, but alludes to the mingling of her own past, present, and future; in a sense, Hannah is always coming back to her.
Chronologically, this is our last, tragic view of Louise in the film; bereaved and heading down a strange hallway, which curves to symbolize her nonlinear perception of time.
But now I'm not so sure I believe in beginnings and endings.

With this line, Louise's narration ushers us into a new time period; what we first assume to be the future, but is instead the past. The next time we see Hannah, it will be after Louise starts learning Heptapod, and starts to see glimpses of the future herself.

Louise's social isolation and emotional numbness -- which we are led to infer, wrongly, to be the result of her daughter's death -- are emphasized by the out-of-focus students in her classroom.  She seems utterly set apart from other people.
Louise briefly portrays Portuguese as a unique language with unusual origins, establishing her expertise and subtly preparing us for how she will later talk about Heptapod.

The Louise-getting-to-her-car sequence does some crucial work in setting up the danger and panic that the world suffers during the Heptapods' visit. After this scene, nearly all of that chaos is depicted in a remote, distant fashion, as something our main characters only experience through news broadcasts; here, the crashing cars and jets overhead unsettle us in a more immediate way, leaving us with the unnerving impression of society falling apart.

Since we ultimately discover that Hannah's birth and death take place in the future, Louise's trauma is only alluded to in scant, vague references like this -- references which make just as much sense when applied to her prior work with the military.
This shot really emphasizes the loneliness of Louise's home by showing a vacant table in the frame behind her.
A wide shot of Louise, tiny in the corner of her large book-filled office, conveys both her solitude and her considerable academic experience.
You made quick work of those insurgents.

It doesn't feel like it on a first viewing, but this is perhaps one of the most important lines of the film. Without it, Louise's emotionally-numb behavior in the film's first act would have no in-universe explanation, and would feel like an unjustified narrative trick to make us think Hannah died in the recent past. With the line, we have an alternate cause for her distant, reserved behavior: her work was recently responsible for people's deaths.
I like how the recorder gets its own closeup, serving as a visual stand-in for the (so far) unknowable aliens.
Now you heard it. What do you make of it?

Colonel Weber's comically impossible first request to Louise is, ironically, a moment of poor communication. It also sets up the challenges ahead very well, conveying both the intellectual challenge of translating Heptapod and the wide gulf between Louise and Weber.
Before you commit to him, ask him the Sanskrit word for war and its translation.
Interestingly, the approach of the US military is depicted like a visit from aliens; strange and powerful blue lights invading Louise's home and a fast, unidentifiable craft zooming over the water.
Gavisti. He says it means "an argument." What do you say it means?

Louise's "test" for the Berkeley translator is an interesting one, foreshadowing a central conflict later in the film. The two linguists offer different interpretations of a violent term; Louise is chosen because she gives a more thorough definition which remains clear and concise. When the Heptapods later use the word "Weapon," it's Louise who once again insists on finding a more nuanced interpretation that allows a chance for peace.
"It is the first weapon drawn in a conflict."
This line foreshadows the nature of the Heptapods' offering; the language itself turns out to be the "weapon" that they allude to.

Louise's expression "dazzle them with the basics" could just as easily refer to a significant portion of the film's first act, which finds entertaining character- and conflict-based methods of explaining the nature of Louise's work.
Yeah, it's great. Even if it's wrong.
This is why you're both here.

Director Denis Villeneuve and cinematographer Bradford Young used the term "dirty sci-fi" to describe the film's aesthetic.  Villeneueve elaborated further, saying that he wanted it to feel like "this was happening on a bad Tuesday morning, like when you were a kid on the school bus on a rainy day and you'd dream while looking out the window at the clouds."  It's a poetic and apt description for the film's unique look.
This long, beautiful soaring shot awes us with the size of the looming Shell, while telling us everything we need to know about the nature and distance of the nearby military encampment.

It's an important detail that the Shells never quite touch Earth's surface.  According to production designer Patrice Vermette, "The twelve identical ships would travel across the universe and end the journey by hovering twenty-eight feet above the ground in delicate equilibrium, leaving it to Earth's people to make the final outreach to contact them."
Louise and the Shell share the frame for the first time, hinting at how closely linked they will ultimately become.

Captain Marks' face is kept front-and-center for a while as he leads Louise and Ian through the tunnel.  The character won't be truly significant for some time, but early shots like this help to cement his face in our memory.
Not everyone is able to process experiences like this.

I love how this sequence sets up the aliens, not as a physical threat, but as a psychological threat. The inclusion of an expert being wheeled away, with no indication of whether his mind will heal from the experience, does a lot of work in this regard.

We cut to a new shot -- one which shows off more subtlety in Amy Adams' performance -- when she answers the question of whether she's pregnant.  

On a first viewing, it's easy to infer that we're seeing Louise being startled by a reference to motherhood, so soon after Hannah's death.  

On subsequent viewings, one can only draw a less dramatic conclusion -- perhaps that she's instead reacting based on a *desire* to later have a child, or even that we're not seeing that unusual a reaction at all.  

It's interesting, too, that Ian is included in the extreme foreground of this shot, far too early in the film for us to know that he's the father of Louise's child.
So, they could suffocate us if they wanted.

The character of Halpern is established perfectly as he draws a suspicious, paranoid conclusion about what the Heptapods could do to humans.  While most of the other human characters show some flexibility in regard to the Heptapods, Halpern remains a staunch, stubborn antagonist throughout.
We can't tell what they're saying when they respond to "hello," so...
So is there any physical contact with the, um...am I the only one having trouble saying "aliens?"

Lines like this do a terrific job of selling the characters' persisting disbelief. As many films as the average viewer has already seen about aliens landing, Arrival manages to make the concept feel original, real, and powerful.
You'll see soon enough. Hurry up.

This is a moment where the film prioritizes suspense over realism; in reality, it's hard to imagine sending someone into an experience like this without giving them as much concrete detail as possible, to help them prepare for it and process it. To have a character describe the Shell so intricately, however, would be to rob the audience of the tense, slow reveal of the following scene, which is easily one of the film's greatest parts.
Jhann Jhannsson's score is hair-raising in moments like this, with blaring chords as strange and overwhelming as the Shell looming over the audience.

It's a simple shot, but one of my favorites in the entire film: Ian's hand brushing softly against the bottom of the Shell. It's close, intimate, tactile, and full of yearning, as his fingers barely make contact, bringing a small and personal dimension to this grand, awesome situation.
The score brings in a low, unsettling hum as the camera approaches the pitch-black square entrance, playing to a common, primal fear of nothingness.
In one action -- and one simple, tilting shot -- the gravity situation within the Shell is concisely, visually explained.

On subsequent viewings, it becomes very interesting to hear the characters' frequent warnings about time; they speak often of their limited window within the Shell, and later on, the ticking-clock situation generated by General Shang's conversations with the Heptapods. To paraphrase Louise's opening narration, time doesn't work the way they think.
The sensation of shifting gravity is aided by the simultaneous, sliding pitch in the score.

Part of what makes the aliens so strange is their utter simplicity; everything about the Shell consists of simple, monochromatic shapes, from the black-oval Shell to the black-square entrance to the white-rectangle screen within.
It's interesting that the screen separating the humans and Heptapods appears to have the same dimensions as the film's own aspect ratio.
The film's story is a patient one, keeping us in suspense for over half an hour before showing the aliens for the first time.

The Heptapods' appearance was inspired by various strange or large animals: octopi, elephants, whales, and spiders.  They also resemble skeletal hands in certain shots, and Denis Villeneuve intended for them to resemble the Grim Reaper late in the film.  Their frightening, surreal appearance helps to misdirect the audience as Louise seeks a peaceful understanding with them.

After all this build-up, Weber ends the scene with a single line which launches Louise's quest and promises more to come. After this brief, tantalizing glimpse of the aliens, the viewer can't help but want to return to the Shell.
These alternating shots of Louise and Ian -- with each one's eyeline pointed very close to the camera -- convey a powerful bonding moment right after they've both seen the unfathomable.

Louise and Ian's distinct reactions to the experience suit each character perfectly; Ian, who's been a source of physical comedy at a few moments up to this point, breaks eye contact to go vomit. Louise, ever mindful of the job, asks if she's fired.

Many of the film's visual compositions make use of screens in the extreme foreground, separating humans from each other just as the humans are separated from the Heptapods. Here, Louise and Ian's work is isolated from the military's.
A big part of what makes this shot so arresting is the frozen posture of the three people watching the news, too entranced by the apocalyptic world events to move.

The soundtrack is interspersed with canary chirps, constantly begging the question of whether the oxygen will suddenly be taken out of the room while the humans are there.  It's a threat the movie never delivers on, but on a first viewing, it helps to keep us on edge.

The Heptapods' visual language was created by Montreal artist Martine Bertrand.  The individual characters representing words and phrases are called "logograms," working similarly to Egyptian heiroglyphics and Chinese characters.

This is one of Louise's more endearing moments for me; energized by her success in the Shell, she stands her ground defiantly against Weber's doubts. Amy Adams brings that newfound energy to the next couple scenes.
Everything you do in there, I have to explain to a room full of men whose first and last question is, "How can this be used against us?" So you're gonna have to give me more than that.

Weber is sometimes an antagonistic figure, but at some points, he's also an avatar for the audience. Here, he explains just why he needs to understand Louise's methods perfectly, prompting her to explain them to him and, by extension, to the audience.
And remember what happened to the Aborigines. A more advanced race nearly wiped them out.

I always found it interesting that Weber uses a fairly offensive phrase, "more advanced race," to compare the Aborigines and European colonizers. His warning carries the obvious, intended threat that the Heptapods could wipe out humanity, but his wording carries the secondary threat of humanity duplicating its past cruelties.

I enjoy the role of the posted-up logograms in the film's production design; as Louise dives deeper into the alien language, the walls become covered with more and more logograms, serving as visual evidence of her ongoing achievement.
The coy question of whether Louise has "met" General Shang turns out to be foreshadowing; by the end of the film, she actually *does* meet Shang in person.

The introduction of a foreign military villain plays on xenophobic anxieties, but only to subvert them when Shang has a change of heart at the end of the film (unlike, say, Halpern, a character who remains an antagonist until his exit from the story).

Little closeups of physical reactions like this contribute to the film's realism, making Louise's worsening stress and sleep deprivation palpable even as they reach the point of a seeming disconnect from reality.
When Louise fails to understand this logogram, she's shown in a higher-angle shot, appearing smaller and less in-control.
The editing becomes much quicker as Louise removes her protective gear, creating a heightened sense of danger.
I was thinking Abbott and Costello.
Ian's names for the Heptapods serve as a reference to Abbott and Costello's best-known routine, "Who's On First," a two-person performance which is based on a series of miscommunications.

On repeat viewings, it becomes clearer that this is Louise's first glimpse of the future, having just learned enough of the Heptapods' language to unsettle her perception of time. This being the case, it's a strange and unclear sequence, with a horse so dark and out-of-focus that it appears almost as alien as the Heptapods. Hannah, too, is only shown in extreme, identity-obscuring closeup, which is appropriate since Louise wouldn't yet recognize her. This moment of foresight carries a clear thematic relevance to Louise's current work; then, as now, she is helping two species to get along and understand one another.
Becky asked me if the monsters are going to kill Daddy!

There's an eerie contrast between the panicked yells on the phone, and the exhausted, determined calm on the face of Captain Marks. It's a memorable, unnerving scene which leads us to fear just what Marks might do.
Here are some of the many things we don't know about heptapods.  Greek.  Hepta, "seven."  Pod, "foot."  Seven feet.  Heptapod.

At nearly the halfway point of the film, Ian's narration brings us into a documentary-style sequence to convey the passage of time and accumulation of knowledge. Ian's incidental name-drop of the Heptapods at the beginning is a great way to indicate, right off the bat, that they've been at work for a while now.

Ian tells us that the Shells have no footprint, just as we are treated to a wide shot of the complete Shell.  The juxtaposition seems to challenge us to look over the Shell's smooth surface, in search of some residue it's leaving behind.

The documentary-style sequence is interspersed with gorgeous, stunning shots of the Shells at their landing sites. This shot shows off the sky reflected in the water below, depicting the Shell floating, suspended, in a seemingly infinite and mysterious expanse.
The next most plausible theory is that Sheena Easton had a hit song at each of these sites in 1980. So, we just don't know.

I like how subtly, yet clearly, Ian's affection for Louise is expressed, in both the writing and Jeremy Renner's performance; in his larger discussion of the Heptapods, he takes time to note, quite earnestly, that Louise is putting them all to shame.
The score is full of momentum and hope, a distinct shift from the foreboding chords which characterized the Heptapods in the beginning.
We have our friends in Pakistan to thank for their study of how heptapods write, because unlike speech, a logogram is free of time.

Ian alludes to increasing international cooperation during one of the film's most hopeful sections. When the "weapon" concept is introduced later on, there's a palpable sense of loss as that collaboration gives way to mistrust.

I guess that's why I'm single.


Trust me, you can understand communication and still end up single.

I absolutely adore the performances of Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner in this scene. There's an endearing wariness as each of them subtly checks to see if the other one is single. All the while, however, the Shell is shown hovering behind Louise's head, hinting at the alien ability which will doom their relationship some day.
The first photograph of the aliens goes viral.

At this point, the Heptapods no longer come across as a narrative threat, but that doesn't change how frightening they look. Seeing this "first photograph," and imagining how panic-inducing it would be without context, reintroduces overreaction by humanity as the primary threat.
Out president's willing to sit back and let them waltz in and take our country.

The anti-alien video host seems to be based on figures like Alex Jones and Rush Limbaugh -- his recording setup, in particular, is strikingly similar to Limbaugh's -- and this line mirrors modern conservative sentiments regarding immigration. The character only appears for a brief scene, so these parallels (along with the ominous banner ad for a gun) help to quickly establish what kind of messaging Captain Marks is receiving.

Even well before we learn the nature of Louise's "flashbacks," the film is unafraid to make them confusing, encouraging us to attribute their strange nature to Louise's stress and sleep deprivation. Here, "what's this word" is said without an accompanying image at first, making Louise turn around as if her daughter's in the room. Given that we've never heard a little girl's voice at this military base, it's easy enough to piece together that the speaker isn't actually present, but the faceless voice is still unsettling for a moment.
Hannah continues to be shown in shallow-focus shots, making her presence feel fleeting and less-than-tangible.  As Louise slips back to the present, Hannah steps out of focus, diminishing to a blur.

This is a scene that takes on much more power on subsequent viewings: it appears to be the moment Louise realizes, on an emotional level, that her not-yet-born daughter will die young.  As she struggles to process this, the Shell hangs in the background, a visual reminder of where this foresight is coming from.

Unconnected to any physical event, we see a glimpse of a Heptapod, blurry and phantomlike in the fog. The context-free image separates us from a clear sense of causality and leads us into Louise's surreal dream sequence.
You know, I was doing some reading, um, about this idea that if you immerse yourself into a foreign langauge, then you can actually rewire your brain.

The Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis is introduced by Ian in Louise's dream. I like the ambiguity of whether Ian actually spoke about it to her, at some point in waking life, or whether Louise is just reflecting on the concept herself, using the image of Ian in her dream to convey the idea. 

The mention of this hypothesis goes a long way toward making the eventual plot twist plausible, without giving away just what it's going to be.

Before we see the Heptapod in Louise's quarters, there are subtler clues that we're watching Louise's dream.  She keeps turning her head from Ian to an unseen party (who is revealed, strangely late, to be the Heptapod), and at one point Ian jarringly switches sides in the frame.
Another clue that Louise is dreaming: the sound of the canary, up to this point associated purely with the Shell.
Well, let's say that I taught them chess instead of English. Every conversation would be a game. Every idea expressed through opposition, victory, defeat.  You see the problem?

To the viewer, the logograms are largely indistinguishable.  The film nevertheless brings a lot of suspense to the "offer weapon" symbol by lingering on reaction shots of Ian and Louise, letting their performances establish why the symbol is so worrying.

The false objective of the Heptapods -- to encourage division among the humans by offering weaponry -- is an interesting-enough possibility that it seems frighteningly plausible.  Had the human characters inferred a simple "Invade and destroy the Earth" plot, the viewer would be inclined to see right through it.
The British with India, the Germans with Rwanda. They even got a name for it in Hungary.

The name Halpern refers to is "szalmitaktika" or "salami tactics." This is one of the film's interesting moments where the humans assume the worst of the Heptapods, based largely on the prior history of humans.
A newly chaotic, frightened mood of the camp is conveyed with fast tracking shots.
In a statement, General Shang said, "China no longer trusts the aliens who want to divide us. Humanity must be protected."

A great, communicative shot, tilting up from the timer to Louise and Ian, showing both how dangerously close they are to the bomb, and how oblivious they are to its timer.  This single shot brings a feeling of heartpounding suspense to the entire scene.

It's a small, throwaway exchange, but I like how it affirms both the impromptu nature of this meeting, as well as Louise and Ian's dedication to performing every step correctly, even when it's off the original plan.

The actual violence on the ground is only depicted through the distant sound of gunshots. The film wisely places all of its emphasis, instead, on Louise and Ian's ordeal, keeping even the results of the shootout mysterious. The film's general aversion to showing physical violence brings extra heft to its climax, when Halpern pulls a gun on Louise and Ian.

Louise's "memories" of Hannah are linked strongly to the sense of touch.  Here, making contact with the Heptapod and its ink through the barrier leads us straight to a closeup of Louise holding Hannah's hand.
The arresting image of Louise and Ian suspended over the entrance ends the scene on a note of uncertainty. It's also the last time the Shell's entry tunnel is shown in the film.
Ah, some soldiers. They've been watching too much TV.

Dr. Kettler uses a curiously dismissive line to explain a very serious insurrection, but his flippance does some vital work for the narrative: it tells the audience that the rogue soldiers won't be back, and that the rest of the film won't be about them.
Hannah once again enters the shot from out-of-focus, seeming to step in from the unknown peripheries of Louise's mind.
If you want science, call your father.

This line reveals that Hannah's father is a scientist, linking the so-far-unseen character to Ian in a stark fashion. On a first viewing, it's a confusing piece of knowledge, driving us toward the film's big reveal in search of further explanation.
It's time you opened that bottle you've been hiding.

Louise's significant glimpse into the immediate future is brief, but it comes in two unforgettable shots, both of which break the "rules" of everything we've seen thus far: a descending Shell that isn't the right shape, and Louise's hands making direct contact with the fog and ink. When the shots recur a little later, we recognize them right away.
It's in the hands of our superiors now.

There's a certain quasi-religious tone to this line, especially since the film has never shown us any of these "superiors." It also establishes a distinct sense of helplessness before Louise's bold gambit to enter the Shell herself.
Here, the score echoes Louise's first entry into the Shell, indicating an equally revelatory experience ahead.
The Heptapod's sounds are more overwhelming and threatening than ever before, renewing a sense of power and danger now that Louise is sharing space with one of them.

The fact that Abbott and Costello both knew, all along, that Abbott would die, recharacterizes the Heptapods not only as friendly visitors, but as extraordinarily benevolent, willing to exchange their lives for a better future. Their foreknowledge also explains why Abbott took a moment to appear in the ticking-bomb scene.

To me, this is one of Amy Adams' most moving line deliveries in the film. The viewer truly gets the sense of a person trying to apologize on behalf of their entire species, knowing that it can't quite be done.

Something that often makes fantasy and sci-fi great is the implication that this fictional world is larger than we'll ever get a chance to see.  The idea that humanity will aid the Heptapods in three thousand years certainly fits this description; the situation is so far-off that it's nearly impossible to picture.  It lights up the imagination.
I don't understand. Who is this child?

Though the film takes a little longer to fully explain the concept, this is the line that essentially reveals the movie's big twist. When I saw this film in a theater, the posture of everyone in the audience suddenly, visibly shifted just as everything clicked into place. 

Upon a second viewing, it's surprising that this twist occurs with under 20 minutes left in the film. It requires the audience to process and reconsider so much information, that this last section of the film ends up feeling much longer.
Louise's slowly-paced march back to the military gives the audience time to process the big reveal, and adjust their understanding of the movie up to this point.
I'm trying to figure it out. This is too big.
He doesn't look at me the same way anymore.
Kind of like you are, with your swimming and your poetry and all the other amazing things that you share with the world.
For me, one of the most heartbreaking moments in the film is this line, when Louise deftly changes the subject to keep Hannah from knowing about her inevitable death.

At a couple points toward the end of the film, Louise is shown to be mid-embrace at different, simultaneously-experienced points in time.  Here, we cut from her embrace of Hannah in the future, to her in Ian's arms in the present.
I just realized why my husband left me.

This exchange between Louise and Ian reminds us of how little Ian -- and by extension, the audience -- really understood about Louise's past. It basically tells us how this new understanding, that Louise's marriage and daughter are in the future, could be possible.
It reads the same forward and backward.
Our quick look at Louise's class in the future shows a very different scene from the beginning: the seats are full now, and Louise appears to teach with more energy and enthusiasm than before.

The immediate future of global diplomacy is hinted at without being fully explained.  The image of several nations' flags hung alongside a Heptapod logogram is an especially fascinating touch, and the open-ended term "unification" is used by General Shang.

As in Louise's scenes with Hannah, a very shallow depth of field is used, leaving only Louise and General Shang in focus.  By separating the two characters from the surrounding action, these shots emphasize the unique, out-of-time history that these two share.
I do not claim to know how your mind works, but I believe it was important for you to see that.

It's interesting how, just as Louise had to comprehend a mindset she could never fully inhabit in order to commune with the Heptapods, now General Shang has to do the same to commune with her. The film optimistically shows some of the most outlandish difficulties in communication to be solvable problems.
You told me my wife's dying words.

The "dying words" Louise speaks to Shang translate to "In war, there are no winners, only widows." Knowing that the phrase is explicitly anti-war brings an extra, fascinating dimension to its use between Louise, Shang, and Shang's departed wife.
I love Jeremy Renner's performance of this line. He conveys not only Ian's determination to shield Louise with his own body, but his understandable fear and confusion in that terrifying moment.
You are committing an act of treason!

After a tense sequence occurring across two timelines, the film momentarily pulls us out of physical reality altogether for a series of news clips against a black backdrop.  This final use of news footage as a storytelling device separates us from the dangerous climax of moments before, and ushers us into the film's peaceful denouement.

In the end, the Shells are shown, not lifting off into space, but evaporating into the atmosphere. It's a striking visual because, even after all we've learned, it reminds us how little we still know; we don't even know if the Shells are teleporting, or if the Shells -- and the Heptapods within -- are dying, making this a suicide mission on their part.
The opening shot recurs, along with the same piece of heartbreaking score, to link the prologue and epilogue together in time.
So, Hannah, this is where your story begins.  The day they departed.
A subtle parallel: Louise knocks on the glass to get Ian's attention, just as the Heptapods and humans would interact with the glass barrier to communicate with each other.

For the first time, we start to see Ian interacting with Hannah.  He uses the nickname "star-stuff," which comes from scientist Carl Sagan's 1973 book, "The Cosmic Connection."  In the original passage, Sagan declared that because humans consist of material that was created within stars, "we are made of star-stuff."  

It's a relevant expression for a film about finding commonality between humans and extraterrestrial visitors. The late introduction of this nickname also helps to convey the tragically short period of time shared by Ian and Hannah; ultimately, we barely see the two of them together at all.
If you could see your whole life from start to finish, would you change things?

Louise voices one of the film's central questions toward the very end. Interestingly, her dilemma is different in the source novella, "Story of Your Life"; in the book, Hannah dies of an easily-avoidable climbing accident at the age of 25, but since Louise has no option to alter her future, the freak accident can't be prevented.

The film instead suggests that Louise *could* change her future if she wanted to, but also combines Hannah's birth and death into the same decision, giving Louise the power to make that difficult choice.

As Louise embraces Ian, she occupies the left side of the frame in the future and the right side in the present, signifying the way she's viewing the central question from two different points in time.

The film ends definitively with Louise's decision to have Hannah, despite knowledge of her death.  I love how the choice is, essentially, shown in two separate expressions: a verbal decision in the future, and a physical decision in the present, where she wholeheartedly embraces Ian and the future that comes with this connection.
